item.title: _Specifiacations
item.description: 1 style: bullet TL;DR you can summarize contents as a table format. or just write down statements you think it is important within 3 lines.

item.title: _WEB
item.description: 1 style: bullet [[Design/Trees/Experiences/WEB/Reserach/_Research]] [[Design/Trees/Experiences/WEB/Wireframing/_Wireframing]] [[Design/Trees/Experiences/WEB/Visualization/_Visualization]] [[_Slicing]]

item.title: Accessibility
item.description: [!tldr] Accessibility Ensure that your website is available to everyone. 1 style: bullet Allowing your pages to respond to different screen sizes is just one way of making sure your website is accessible to as many people as possible.

item.title: Accessibility tests
item.description: 1 style: bullet Accessibility tests Accessibility is the practice of making websites inclusive to all. That means supporting requirements such as: keyboard navigation, screen reader support, touch-friendly, usable color contrast, reduced motion, and zoom support.

item.title: API
item.description: 1 style: bullet Open API Specification

item.title: Args
item.description: 1 style: bullet Args A story is a component with a set of arguments that define how the component should render.

item.title: Automate
item.description: 1 style: bullet # How to automate UI tests with Github Actions Speed up your workflow and ship higher quality of code Developers spend 4-8 hrs a week fixing bugs.

item.title: Browse stories
item.description: 1 style: bullet Browse Stories Last chapter, we learned that stories correspond with discrete component states. This chapter demonstrates how to use Storybook as a workshop for building components.

item.title: Build pages and screens
item.description: 1 style: bullet Building pages with Storybook Storybook helps you build any component, from small “atomic” components to composed pages.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: 1 style: bullet Conclusion Congratulations! You learned the basics. Storybook is the most popular tool for UI component development and documentation.

item.title: Data exchange
item.description: 1 style: bullet JSON Schema

item.title: Decorators
item.description: 1 style: bullet Decorators A decorator is a way to wrap a story in extra “rendering” functionality. Many addons define decorators to augment your stories with extra rendering or gather details about how your story renders.

item.title: Embed
item.description: 1 style: bullet Embed stories Embed stories to showcase your work to teammates and the developer community at large.

item.title: Entity Relationship Diagram
item.description: 1 max_depth: 3 Entity Relationship Diagrams 🌱 An entity–relationship model (or ER model) describes interrelated things of interest in a specific domain of knowledge.

item.title: Flowchart
item.description: 1 max_depth: 3 Flowcharts - Basic Syntax All Flowcharts are composed of nodes, the geometric shapes and edges, the arrows or lines.

item.title: Guide for full-stack-fastapi-postgresql repo
item.description: 1 2 style: bullet max_depth: 3 Backend Requirements Docker. Docker Compose. Poetry for Python package and environment management.

item.title: Icons
item.description: [!tldr] Icons Use SVG for scalable responsive iconography. 1 style: bullet Most images are part of your content, but icons are part of your user interface.

item.title: Import stories in tests
item.description: 1 style: bullet Import stories in tests Teams test a variety of UI characteristics using different tools. Each tool requires you to replicate the same component state over and over.

item.title: Install
item.description: 1 style: bullet Install Storybook Use the Storybook CLI to install it in a single command. Run this inside your existing project’s root directory:

item.title: Interaction
item.description: [!tldr] Interaction Prepare your pages for different input mechanism; mouse, keyboard, and touch. 1 style: bullet Small screen devices like mobile phones often have touchscreens.

item.title: Interaction tests
item.description: 1 style: bullet Interaction tests As you build more complex UIs like pages, components become responsible for more than just rendering the UI.

item.title: Internationalization
item.description: [!tldr] Internationalization Prepare your designs for different languages and writing modes. 1 style: bullet The World Wide Web is available to everyone in the world—it’s right there in the name!

item.title: Introduction
item.description: 1 style:bullet Introduction to addons Addons extend Storybook with features and integrations that are not built into the core.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: 1 style: bullet Introduction to Storybook for React Storybook is a tool for UI development. It makes development faster and easier by isolating components.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: 1 style: bullet How to test UIs with Storybook Storybook provides a clean-room environment for testing components in isolation.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: 1 style: bullet How to write stories A story captures the rendered state of a UI component. It’s a function that returns a component’s state given a set of arguments.

item.title: joins Between Tables
item.description: 1 2 style: bullet max_depth: 4 2.6. Joins Between Tables Thus far, our queries have only accessed one table at a time.

item.title: Loaders
item.description: 1 style: bullet Loaders (experimental) Loaders (experimental) are asynchronous functions that load data for a story and its decorators.

item.title: Macro layouts
item.description: [!tldr] Macro layouts Design page layouts using a choice of CSS techniques. 1 style:bullet Macro layouts describe the larger, page-wide organization of your interface.

item.title: Markdown
item.description: CommonMark Spec

item.title: Media features
item.description: [!tldr] Media features A round-up of all the ways that media features let you respond to devices and preferences.

item.title: Media queries
item.description: [!tldr] Media queries Adapt your designs to different screen sizes using CSS media queries. 1 style: bullet Designers can adjust their designs to accommodate users.

item.title: Micro layouts
item.description: [!tldr] Micro layouts Build flexible components that can be placed anywhere 1 style: bullet When we think of layouts, we often think of page-level designs.

item.title: My issues
item.description: 1 style: bullet Frequently used Commands configs Activate git hooks with Husky 1 2 3 4 npx husky-init && npm install # npm npx husky-init && yarn # Yarn 1 yarn dlx husky-init --yarn2 && yarn # Yarn 2+ pnpm dlx husky-init && pnpm install # pnpm Add emoji in commit message with githook using gitmoji-cli To initialize hooks in husky, do this :

item.title: Naming components and hierarchy
item.description: 1 style: bullet Naming components and hierachy The title of the component you export in the default export controls the name shown in the sidebar.

item.title: Parameters
item.description: 1 style: bullet Parameters Parameters are a set of static, named metadata about a story, typically used to control the behavior of Storybook features and addons.

item.title: Play function
item.description: 1 style: bullet Play function Play functions are small snippets of code executed after the story renders. Enabling you to interact with your components and test scenarios that otherwise required user intervention.

item.title: Publish
item.description: 1 style:bullet Publish Storybook Teams publish Storybook online to review and collaborate on works in progress. That allows developers, designers, PMs, and other stakeholders to check if the UI looks right without touching code or requiring a local dev environment.

item.title: Relational database
item.description: 1 style: bullet TL;DR Situation most cases to save datas. Thoughts Maybe need to normalize datas.

item.title: Responsive images
item.description: [!tldr] Responsive images Give your visitors the most appropriate images for their devices and screens. 1 style:bullet Text on the web automatically wraps at the edge of the screen so that it doesn’t overflow.

item.title: Screen configurations
item.description: [!tldr] Screen configurations Prepaare your content for devices with multiple screens. 1 style: bullet Responsive web design was in many ways a reaction to mobile phones.

item.title: Sequence Diagram
item.description: 1 max_depth: 3 Sequence diagrams A Sequence diagram is an interaction diagram that shows how processes operate with one another and in what order.

item.title: Setup
item.description: 1 style: bullet Setup Storybook Now that you’ve learned what stories are and how to browse them, let’s demo working on one of your components.

item.title: Snapshot tests
item.description: 1 style:bullet Snapshot tests Snapshot tests compare the rendered markup of every story against known baselines. It’s a way to identify markup changes that trigger rendering errors and warnings.

item.title: Stories for multiple components
item.description: 1 style: bullet Stories for multiple components It’s useful to write stories that render two or more components at once if those components are designed to work together.

item.title: Test runner
item.description: 1 style: bullet Storybook test runner turns all of your stories into executable tests. It is powered by Jest and Playwright.

item.title: The picture element
item.description: [!tldr] The picture element Exercise more creative control over your images. 1 style: bullet The previous module demonstrated how the srcset attribute allows you to provide different-sized versions of the same image.

item.title: Theming
item.description: [!tldr] Theming Adapt your design to match user preferences such as a dark mode. 1 style: bullet Even branding can be responsive.

item.title: Typography
item.description: [!tldr] Typography Make your text legible and beautiful, no matter where it appears. 1 style: bullet If you don’t specify any styles for your text, browsers will apply their own default styles.

item.title: User interface patterns
item.description: [!tldr] User interface patterns Consider some scommon UI elements that adopt to differenet screen sizes. 1 style: bullet A design viewed on a small screen shouldn’t look like a shrunk-down version of a large-screen layout.

item.title: Visual tests
item.description: 1 style: bullet Visual tests Visual tests, also called visual regression tests, catch bugs in UI appearance. They work by taking screenshots of every story and comparing them commit-to-commit to identify changes.

item.title: What's a story
item.description: 1 style: bullet What’s a story A story captures the rendered state of a UI component. Developers write multiple stories per component that describe all the “interesting” states a component can support.

item.title: Why storybook
item.description: 1 style: bullet The problem The web’s universality is pushing more complexity into the frontend. It began with responsive web design, which turned every user interface from one to 10, 100, 1000 different user interfaces.

item.title: Write
item.description: 1 style: bullet Write an addon One of Storybook’s main features is its robust addon ecosystem. Use addons to enhance and extend your development workflow.

item.title: Write a preset
item.description: 1 style: bullet Write a preset Storybook preset addons are grouped collections of babel, webpack, and addons configurations that support specific use cases in Storybook, such as TypeScript or MDX support.

item.title: 🎉CSS
item.description: 1 style: bullet Map of contents Draw a simple excalidraw scatch to understand how contents are constructed and networked.
